awd_titl_txt: Dissecting the molecular players essential for polar growth in Agrobacterium
awd_abstract_narration:
This project has the potential to change our understanding of growth in bacteria. During bacterial growth the cell wall is typically understood to enlarge by the dispersed generation of new wall material. However, it is now known that some important agricultural and pathogenic bacteria expand their cell walls during growth by adding new material at the ends (poles) of the cells. This project will elucidate the mechanisms of polar growth in Agrobacterium and the manner in which polar growth is integrated with cell division. The project will provide a postdoctoral fellow and graduate student advanced training in plant science, and the PI will engage in public outreach with lectures at museums and during the University's CalDay public open house event. The PI will also teach a course a course on "The Secret Life of Plants" to non-science major undergraduates that emphasizes social, environmental and economic aspects. 


The project will elucidate the mechanisms of polar growth in bacteria, addressing the following specific issues: 1) Defining the proteins that comprise the Agrobacterium polar growth machinery, using full-length and Agrobacterium specific sub-domains of FtsA, FtsZ, PopZ, PopJ, LDT-0845, and TipN as bait in yeast two hybrid screens to identify novel interacting partners. 2) Genetic depletion of essential Agrobacterium cell cycle factors to determine their primary phenotypes, using riboswitch technology to acutely deplete cells of FtsA, FtsZ, PopZ, PodJ, LDT-0845, and TipN and using time-lapse fluorescence deconvolution and high resolution structured illumination microscopy (SIM). 3) The role of Agrobacterium TipN-At as a potential polar growth organizing center.

por.por_cntn:
Our long-term research aimed to decipher the remarkable ability of the soil bacterium Agrobacterium tumefaciens to genetically transform plant cells. Agrobacterium is well known and utilized to transfer DNA to plants for basic and applied research.  Our own studies have always been fundamental versus applied and have led to new biological concepts such as 1) small plant molecules made at plant wound sites are perceived by the nearby Agrobacteria in the surrounding soil and provoke the bacteria to activate expression of virulence (vir) genes; 2) vir genes produce proteins that mediate the synthesis of a transferable DNA copy and a secretion system for export of the DNA through the membranes of the bacterium into the plant cell. For about ~ 25 years our research focused on the topology and function of the vir secretion system, which serves as a model for similar secretion systems used by numerous animal pathogens for export of toxins into their respective hosts.

 

Then ten years ago, our research took a new turn when we set out to study how Agrobacterium grows and divides to create new cells. Unexpectedly we found that Agrobacterium does not grow along the entire length of the cell, as abundantly documented in model bacterial systems such as Escherichia coli; when these latter cells elongate to twice their starting length, they divide in the middle to produce two cells. In striking contrast, Agrobacterium grows from only one end of the parent cell; once new growth produces a new compartment equal in size to the old compartment, the parental cell divides in the middle to produce two cells. This type of growth is termed “polar” growth. Polar growth has not been well studied to date and must require specialized mechanisms and new or repurposed proteins for 2 major reasons. 1) In cells that grow along their lengths, the midpoint of a freshly divided cell remains the future (midpoint) site of cell division regardless of cell length. In contrast, the midpoint of a recently divided polar growing cell is not the site where division will occur in daughter cells. Intriguingly, instead the division site (in polar growing cells) becomes two new growth poles in siblings. 2) The genes that produce the proteins that promote growth along the length of bacterial cells (as in E.coli) are absent in Agrobacterium, and this lack suggests there must be new and undiscovered proteins that mediate polar growth.

 

Polar growth implies each end of the Agrobacterium cell is different: the end that grows is called the growth pole (GP), and the end that does not grow is called the old pole (OP). Our research aimed to identify proteins that locate to the GP or OP. We found two proteins that locate to the GP; these proteins then go to the middle of the cell when the cell divides into two cells, placing them exactly where they are needed to act at GPs in the new daughter cells. Another protein locates to the OP while the GP is growing, and then migrates to the GP when the GP is finished growing; this migration of an OP protein causes the GP to become an OP.

 

We observed the dynamic localization of GP versus OP proteins, by fusing these proteins with another protein that is fluorescent so we can observe the glowing proteins under a microscope equipped to detect fluorescence. One GP and one OP protein were seen as small bright fluorescent spots at either end of the bacterial cell. Another GP localized protein was seen as a fluorescent ring encircling the GP; this large dramatic structure implies that the protein may act to form a structural foundation for other proteins to assemble at the GP during polar growth. All proteins we identified (two at the GP and one and the OP) are essential, since if we make genetic alterations of these proteins the bacterial cells cannot survive.

 

More and more investigators are studying bacteria that cause disease in animal cells, and some of these new bacterial systems also grow by “polar” growth; thus, our studies will help decipher how some pathogenic bacteria grow and divide. For example, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, also utilizes polar growth strategies. In general, our studies also provide insight into the evolution of function of essential bacterial proteins.
